Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.

p.note:
CAIRO MUNICIPALITY.
Property owners in Cairo collect high rents. q pay x minimum of taxes, and have very few f accessory expenses. They live very happily, under a Government which imposes what one might reasonably term an item of taxation when considering all the hundred and one j operations connected with the administration, of an extensive city. Among them are such significant details., as lighting and cleaning the town, macadamising and asphalting life roads, care of square, public gardens, schools. museums, libraries, hospitals, and d bridge, not to mention the extinction of fires. And yet, despite the fact that all these arrangements are carried out completely, it appears that some discontented ones are asking for diversions in the shape of the creation of a Municipality. But would such a pleasing alteration of things as they at present exist be feasible or politic, or bring about greater economy. In cosmopolitan countries such as Egypt where so many different nationalities jostle each other, to expect discussion with any degree or accord in a Municipal Council. chosen wholly or in part by the popular rote is to anticipate the impossible. What harmony could ever be supposed to exist in. an assem­bly composed, let us say, of Arabs Mussul­mans, Copts, Persians, Negroes, Mograbins. Turks, Armenians, Syrian*, Greeks, and Italians, with, in addition, a minority of French, Germans, Austrians, Russians, and English, not to speak of other nationalities or , those who are simply "proteges." And this point is to be especially borne in mind, for amongst these individuals one would End a large number with but a passing interest in the country and whose main ambition is to make their respective fortunes in the least possible. Space of time and afterwards return to their native countries. It is therefore fairly evident that these people would consider chiefly the interests of the moment and endeavor in many cases to procure immediate advantages, peculiarly profitable to themselves, without preoccupying this minds with the true in­terests of the town and the future conse­quences involved in the measures they ordain. The warnings afforded by the irregularities omitted in Alexandria are allowed into re­main in beautiful abnormity by those eager for I reform- An honorable and a just Municipality has been extolled. But the ideas put forward by these would be reformers are all purely theoretical. They are idle fancies and unworthy of consideration. A new Administration of this gender organised at Cairo would be even worse that existing at Alexandria, for its com­position would not his in the major part European. Considerable funds are necessary to properly conduct a Municipality, but this is considered a trifle by those who exalt the idea. To procure the necessary revenue for the suggested future Municipal Treasury in perspective namely, something about LB.250,000 or possibly more, all kinds of new imposts are proposed, snob as taxes on beasts of burden and carriages, toll rights, taxes on comestibles, forage, cattle, building materials, etc., etc. In consequence, therefore, all the reforms benefiting almost the whole of the Cairo public inaugurated under the guidance of Lord Cromer, would totally disappear.
The Public Services of Cairo are entirely in the hands of the Egyptian Government, which has all the moans and personnel sufficient for all purposes, and it would be ridiculous to assert that they are not as well administer­ed as existing circumstances allow. The Mi­nistry of Public Works, excepting of course the Irrigation Department, may be considered as very advantageously replacing a Municipal­ity, which, even admitting that it was perfect, could never be served by a more competent staff. The Capital is otherwise more favored than other towns in Egypt where Councils have been established. It is precisely to this privileged situation that Cairo owes the numerous improvements with which the town has been endowed of recent years, as well as the creation of new quarters where roads were planned by the Government and land I offered to the public on moot reasonable terms. If the price of building sites has been quadrupled in the best quarters of Cairo, enrich­ing many, the merit therefore descends prin­cipally on the Government, which has done everything possible to beautify the town and still continues to expend very largely with the same object. Simply to asphalt the streets in the native quarters, for example, the Public Works expends actually £20,000 a year, whilst a new bridge over the Nile is undertaken at a cost of nearly £200,000. This new bridge, opening up as it will a passage to property on the right of the river, serves to extend the town and bring about the formation of other new quarters, and without its costing a penny to Cairenes, bat on the contrary offering increased resources to the investor. One cannot reproach the Government in respect of not keeping in line with progress. The in­auguration of the tramway service is due to the Government’s initiation, and it is very capable that wherever the tramways have pene­trated the general aspect of the quarters his been transformed, the roads are well main­tained, and congenial new buildings have been erected. Moreover, the introduction of this service has very largely contributed towards the increased value of land on the outskirts as to drinking Water, it will be remembered the Ministry of Finance granted the Water Company last year nearly £40,000 towards the installation of artesian wells and new pumping machinery at Rod el Fang. These expenses have been incurred for the express purpose of endowing Cairo with drinking water of the very first quality, and all this without the
exaction of any additional taxation.
Studying the procedure of “exhausting" the L.E. 250,000 annual expenditure deem­ed necessary, the argument is brought for­ward that among other things seweres might be laid down, and for the purpose, over and above the before mentioned taxes, all the houses of the Capital could be specially taxed. It is well known that the sanitary conditions of Cairo are to-day good, and will compare favorably with those of the principal cities in Europe, For many years, it is trues the mortality tables were based on a population well under the correct figures, and consequently formed an exaggerated percentage, but since the last census it is proved beyond all doubt that the death-rate in the Capital is really normal. Among the European section this varies between 23 and 25 per thousand. All arguments, then, in favor of sewers based on the figures of the mortality, are without foundation. But would anyone care to realize what these sewers would cost 1 Sir William Willcocks’s scheme, which merely provided for the damage of part of the town only, fixed the primary outlay at £600,000, plus the enormous sum of £70,000 for annual maintenance. Now it is precisely this low death rate in Cairo that has induced the Government to deliberate twine, and to await the development of the new quarters before undertaking expansive work which, when completed, would reach very probably the total amount of £1,000,000, not to count an annual expenditures of £100,000 for up-keep. The Government indeed several years ago laid down quite a network of rain­water drains which hare gives excellent results and demand but a very small Outlay for main­tenance. This network will be extended in proportion to the advance made with the asphalting being laid down in the native quarters. The Public Works have in addition achieved the long boulevard that branches off from Kasr el Nil leading to the railway sta­tion; the prolongation of this Abbas boulevard will be accomplished very shortly. A destruc­tor for the purpose of burning the refuse of the town is erected;palatial barracks for the City Fire Brigade are completed, besides other improvements too numerous to mention. Realizing all that the Government has done in the past, we may well assume that it will continue in the same direction during too future, now that the Anglo-French Convention releases it from the difficulties hitherto experienced in obtaining from the Caisse de la Dette the necessary finances for all the purposes of administration. It may be farther remarked-that new bridges over the Nile are contemplated, also other measures for the general improve­ment and embellishment of the town are under consideration and all is accomplished without any surtax. But notwithstanding, the mild pro­posal is beard that others than the Govern­ment should take in hand the reins of the administration of the town and determine and administer the requisite revenue inviting further impositions on Cairo proprietors, com­mercial and industrial concerns, and too public in general ; besides, be it remembered, de­manding a revival of all the vexatious taxes suppressed after patient effort. It is even asserted that if the new means of revenue set forth by these would-be administrators were insufficient for the needs of the "Cairo Muni­cipality" they could be augmented by count­less other new imposts. Those who appreciate the Government’s work—and it cannot but be appreciated—should in the general interests protest against such ridiculous proposals, for they are directly opposed to the present pri­vilege enjoyed here of being exempted from taxes—excepting Customs due# and taxes on building property. To anyone acquainted with the situation of business affairs here and the many obstacles encountered in establishing industries in this country with a view to pros­per, the above-mentioned proposals in favour of special taxes, to obtain annually a fabulous sum to scatter to the winds, most appear altogether preposterous.

p.note:
TENDERS are called for by the steamers mid Boats Department Sudan Government for the supply of food, wine and spirits, et&, on the Sudan and Post Steamers and running between Shallal and Holla and vice versa.
The conditions under which the contract will be given can be seen at the following Offices: — financial Secretary Sudan Cairo Assistant Director Steamers and Boats Assouan -and the Director of Steamers and Boats Khartoum North.
Tenders are to be sent, to the Director Steamers and Boats Khartoum North and must be in his Office no later than April 16, 1905
A statement showing experience is to accompany tender.
The contract will before one year ending 17th May 1906. The department of Steamers and Boats does not bind itself to accept the lowest of any tender.

div.head: Maple & Co.
div.p: The Largest, and Most Convenient Furnishing Establishment in the World HUNDREDS of THOUSANDS of POUNDS WORTH OF HIGH-CLASS FURNITURE, BEDSTEADS, BEDDING, CUTLERY, CHINA, GLASS, SILVER WARE, CARPETS, CURTAINS, BLINDS, &c., always ready for immediate shipment. A house furnished throughout in three days.

The “Cathcart ” Dining-Room Suite in Mahogany, Walnut or Fumed Oak, with brass mountings, consists of 6 ft Sideboard with handsomely carved pediment and panels, bevelled mirrors in back, lower portion usefully fitted with drawers, cupboards and cellarette; 3 ft 6 in Silver Cabinet, extreme height 7 ft fitted with clear glass shelves and mirrored back; 3 ft 6 in Dinner Wagon with two drawers and cupboard; Dining Table 4 ft wide and extending to 8 ft long, with extra leaves and patent screw; six very strong Dining Room Chairs with carved backs, upholstered in best marone morocco: Price includes packing and delivery F.O.B. London .. £70 0 0
Separate prices on application
“ONE of the SIGHTS of LONDON”

Maple & Co invite residents of Cairo, Alexandria, Damanhour, Tantah, Mansourah, Damietta, Samahud, Rosetta, Miniah, Ismailla, Port Said, and districts, when visiting London to walk through these spacious showrooms and galleries, and see for themselves all the latest novelties and new productions. MAPLE & CO also send patterns of all kinds of material, and illustrations of furniture, bedsteads, &c., on application, and give Inclusive f.o.b. estimates when desired.
TOTTENHAM COURT ROAD LONDON ENGLAND

div.head: THE ASSOUAN DAM
div.p: SIR WM. WILLCOCKS AND HIS CRITICS

Sit Wm. Willcocks writes —As the contro­versy about the Assouan bits interest many who are not hydraulic lie engineers by, profession, I here wake an attempt to explain the matter a popular manner. I do this with the less hesitation. because, though in the nuclei. I world it was believed that no mortal toted the veil of Isis and lived, and were hidden away oil built hearts connected by subterranean passages with the river our world unity of us live with and find her often. Now waterexerts equal- pressure in every direction against any object which restrains it, and consequently the water held up in the Assouan reservoir pie vast horizontally against the clan where it touches it and strives to throw it over If this Same water Can find its way under the dam through porous veins or weak it exerts this silly up the bullion of theand to its The .Lm call re be to two pressures r one certain and, trying to it uncertain and acting vertically upward.-, try Lag to lift it off everywhere and at all times. The wily when such are present as of its being exerted.

When the Delta Barrage was taken in ISSI this question was thoroughly thrashed out and ample allowance me Bee word of in paragraph of page 260 andthe diagram 269 of the second edition "bgypuau Irrigation.” At the Barrage, allowance was made for as at the who were, sandy Bee the bottom para graph page 26 and the bottom diagram page 27 of ‘Egyptian Weirs and Regulators." While some landslip engineers have laid more the upward vertical pressure of the water, others have insisted that the waterunder pressure moves away particles of saint from unsound horizontal strata and undermines the work and thus causes settlement. Both " views ore tenable. was oil this account that 1 refused have anything to do with dams built on Egyptian sandstone or limestone. Such rucksin Egypt are all horizontally stratified and dangerous. If they had been stratified vertically or at a steep inclination, they would have been sale on head. Granite, if you godown deep is specially good on this bead. Its veins, if well followed down (and they were well followed down at Assouan), become narrow and practically always vertical (they Were vertical at Assouan). It is on this account that 1 have no fears for the raised Assouan during along its entire length where the lab under sluices are provided the apron is the roughly repaired, and the ordinary system of ware flails constructed on the repaired aprons, such as are constructed below all waste weirs or allot they have been The only part of the whole data which I consider urn sound is a small length of solid dam between the Duke of Connaught's foundation stone and the sluice on the East. Here the dam was built on poor stuff. At the lime was built in strongly advocated throwing on earthen bank upstream of this making the bank some Su meters wide and planting a garden on it This would have looked well until rendered the place absolutely stable. The water would never have come near it I contend should be done to-day whether tin* dam is raised or not raised. Bat this is no part- of the dam proper, it is, only a mason try wall tying the dam to the eastern bluff of granite which here bounds the Nile Valley.

Summing up we may say that at the Assouan dam we have against, us: (!) the known calculable forces vi the water trying to over­turn the and (2) certain other greatly minimised but possible trying to lift it its base. We have for: (1) the whole weight of the darn, which with wide factors of safety is capable of resisting all the known forces by it.- weight alone; (2) we have a structure built the most tortuous cement in while in our calculations we have assumed that it is built of mud ; (3) we have a rock whoso veins are noto­riously vertical therefore safe, and moreover thaws veins are bounded on either aide by solid granite to which the dam is tied by neat cement thrown in by thousands of barrels, while hour calculations wo have assumed that we might have thrown in so much plum .yam • and (4) we have a foundation taken down into granite rock regardless of expense and supervised in every detail by sound on general. When therefore we are in a position to • ward off all forces which can come against us, and moreover have armed on reel with extraordinary auxiliaries to help m against all. possible adversaries, and chosen our own ground and deliberately pre­pared it with ungrudging expenditure of money ; when we have done all these things, then at the critical moment to be prepared to stand our ground in perfect bums, is soldiership in War, it is soldiership . in engineering.

div.head: EGYPT'S MINES
div.p: WIDTH AND RICHNESS OF REEFS,
LEGITIMATE SPECULATIVE
OPPORTUNITIES AT PRESENT.

For a proper appreciation of the extent of gold areas Egypt and the Sudan (a correspond cm) the historic recommends- , lion of study of a big map is particularly applicable. Although these gold areas begin in Br? Ia. Egypt proper, it is away in the vast territory of the Sudan, that has now been brought under a "T**., 'settled Government, that meat extensive golds aids am believed to exist; and when, it is realised that one company alone held a concession of 22,000 square miles of territory,or about three times the sire of Wales, someidea can be formed of the potentialities of gold mining in that country in the future. If recourse bad to a big map that also shows products of it will be seen that this supposed and laud is surprisingly fertile, as shorn in a recent article on the development of Egypt; and side by side with the cultivation the land there will be tumid shortlyactive population, that will test laud some Lite wealth that to lie ancient glory undying
the special mining of the how in a recent article on Egyptian

and Sudan mines, the desert may be idealised into the “Garden of Allah," but one to provide the carriage heavy miles of Sand, or if one bail to spend years prospecting in its most forbidding, a prey, of like of not, to au over-growing depression, much of tins would disappear. It is not in the desert that ideals disappear but, as already shown, tins Sudan is all while, as how is conscience, It has evidently not the the I'm, nor deprived idealism, can telegraph that ho has crushing for 2,000 years." That to ancient workings in to what we recently described the all yet discovered gold areas. They simply wild ancient workings, whether in Egypt, on the shores of the wear, or in, score of wiles away from the banks of the Nile, goes on to say that courage everything in the desert proceeds at a deadly slow pace.

In the absence of modern transport facilities that, of course, is inevitable, but what can in the Way of promptitude is proved by the progress made at the Urn company commenced working in January of “JU'k61 nut year, stud have sunk & shaft to a depth of at each 100-lL mill boa been emoted. A well been sunk, and two evaporator plants erected. A light railway five and a-half miles long the mice to, whence communication with duet by the company’s steamer is made, we started early in the year, and was promote ready use by July. Further, the installation has neon effected, so that as faras expedition is concerned there is little to complain of with regard to this company. all day Coining to, at the Dermal mine, which is the extrusive of the Egypt and Syndicate, development work is being actively pursued. Hero also a light railway is being constructed,and a light railway appears likely to be a necessary part of the of the Sudan mince. This moons, ol course, an important adequacy additional outlay that will swell working capital, but ultimately there light railways are family likely to prove profitable investments. In such a Hat country cost is relatively small, while to among other advantages railways-will remove the present deadly blow here of hold, place Egyptian mining on equality me moot expeditious areas elsewhere. Already on this property some hundred feet of good ground have been driven through,and as soon aa the winding engines have been erected, the of the reef to depths will be.
Another reel known as the Red Hill, situated 350 ft to the north, is being worked, and, there also prospects are reported as highly encouraging. the Egyptian concession held '

by this syndicate work is being pursued at two centres. At the brat-named place the repot e says the prospects continue very promising on the whole. The of No. 3 shaft is being pushed on. At Berber, where a prospecting license his been obtained for three years, operationist were actively commended in December last. Front the mine the report comes that the reefs are of great promise, and the place only on second to that of Um Nabardi in the one particular of smaller area worked. The average will of the reef worked is estimated at over 2 ft., and at places the pro 6 ft wide. Only one small ion of the reef be found in situation a fair taken from this of gold per ton, would I two samples taken from abroad and die foot wall the panned and respectively.
A stilill later report on tins property Mays that the drive into reef in the face was ft. wide, of solid on result was estimating
ml at 2j yis. of gold per ton.

There reports are evidently tire outcome of development work since the “Economists mining commissioner was in the Sudan. He says in the case of the Um Rus the reef was only about 1 ft. wide, and at Om Naherdi he judged it at even less, while the case of the Nile places the average width at 2 ft The average width of the Um Rus mine proves to the 1 ft. 7 in.; 'in the other case* his assumption has been equally faulty. But while minimising this characteristic of the reel, the the value is usually above the average, being something Over The Nile Vallev results are sufficient establish this, while assays from other properties, as brown above, equally establish the fact and (rear out the view of the “BMooinist’s" com- missioner that the evidence of the existence of gold in Egypt and the Button to strung enough to warrant the spending of a lot of money on exploratory work, and he further lays that there to no reason why save ml millions should not be laid out in such work with reasonable hopes of getting 4 return.

ln the admitted richness of their Egyptian Sudanese reel* by a critic not disposed to optimism will be found the justification for the interest that is being aroused for. Egyptian in undertakings. To deprecate speculation under such conditions is to ignore the special of milling vendor, as well as some of the marked characteristics of human nature. That the Stock Exchange, realising the possibilities of the future, should discount it up to a certain point is also in­evitable, but this to done nut only iu mining, tout .in every security in which it is possible to create mi interest. What oan be and should Le prevented, however, is rigging the market, mid raging is only possible under certain condi­tion. which a very striking illustration has just been, in that much-manipulated section to. very far wrong if they get in round about, present- prices, which, in market, may .Still Ire as the ground floor in the majority of cases.

div.head: THE GERMAN AS A HUSBAND
div.p: BY ELLA IIEPWORTH DIXON.

p.note:
Anglo-German marriages have been so fre­quent for the lost fiity yean that there must ire by now quite a hotly of expert evidence aa to their success. I think it has been conclu­sively proved that, on the whole, the Teuton, with ''management," oan be made into a tolerably strviceable husband, suitable lor hard wear.
Oho of these experts, the charming Elizabeth of the ’'German Garden," has certainly en­couraged her young compatriots to take unto themselves subjects of the Kaiser as partners in life. Though she usually playfully alludes to her lord and mas ter aa ihe Man ol Wrath, it is tolerably clear that the sympathy between them is intense, that the April, May, and June babies have a pattern lather, and their mother—dare we whisper it T—a somewhat long suffering husband,
Tiie average Teuton docile, faithful, domestic creature, who, once married, to usually devoted to his wife.. It to true that the lady, from financial considerations, has occasionally to give a hand in the kitchen ami to be busier about the house than her Euglish prototype, but I do nut know that she is any the worse for that, and she is moat certainly os intellectual and as accomplished as the English wile, who has literally nothing to du ail day between bresklast and dinner, 'ihe German bourgeois likes to be with his womeu- hind, and in the University towns especially the home life of tho Gurmaua is as oharming. as it is cultivated. Good music plays a large part in the amusement and recreation of the Teuton; he will .travel twenty or thirty mile* of au evening to see a play by Shakespeare adequately performed, and the public music gardens and calfo have a great vogue with lamilj parties.
It to true there are occasionally drawbacks to the German as husband. The Teuton has a genius lor detail which, applied to the house­hold, to sometimes disconcerting. I remember ihe cose of a beautiful, diaphanous English girl, brought up in the most extravagant Luxury, who nuuried a German and found that a serious grievance had arisen because she bad omitted to utilise the pea-shucks as food! Her particular Teuton could not endure waste. It is, however, in hts favor that the German seldom or never makes p hasty and imprudent marriage. He chooses hfo wife with care, often puts her to the ordeal of a seven-years' engage­ment (during which she Cannot escape, for a Gorman betrothal, formally* announced in the newspapers, to well nigh aa binding as the marriage ceremony), and once having singled her out he usually bus tows on her a life-long fidelity and regard.

DIRECTORS' REPORT.
The sixth ordinary general meeting of this company will be held in London on the 14th lost The following is the text of the Directors' report vj- The Directors submit herewith Ihe balance sheet onjd profit and loss account of the com­pany f. t tha j-ear ending 30 th September,190J, duly audited and certified. Changes have oc­curred in the administration of your company daring the put year. It was thought that a more successful working of the company's busi- nees could be brougLt about by the board of directors being situated in Cairo, where it would be in close touch with- the mill The chairman of the company (Mr. Gilea Atherton) and the | board, consisting of MerereT Albert Johnson! Alfred Smith) and Thordaa Stoker, not wishing to stand in the way of this, retired in the early part of this year, and the followibg gentleman were elected to their plaoee : — Mr. Dridor BUbogen (EL Orosdi-Baak, Paris), chairman, Mr. Philip Back (manager, Et Omsdi-Back, Cairo), Mr, Max Roomer (EL Oroedi-Efeck, Cairo), Mr- Samuel H Cookson (manager, the Anglo-Egyptian Bilik, XJsirb). Mr. Simeoce Arbib (Messrs. A, Arbib & Sons, Cairo), j A scheme for raising more working capital, which was in progress at the last gene­ral meeting, held in January, wss completed by the issue,of £20,000 secohd debentures in March but £12,000 were taken up 1>y the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Ltd-, and Et Qroedi- Bahk in equal parts as security for an advance of £5,000 by each of the parties, and £8,000 were left in the hands of the board. A num­ber of drawbacks have taken place in the work­ing of the mil! during .the past year. Financial difficulties involved the working of short time iluring October, November, and December la«L ind;brought the mill to a complete stanrt- •till at the cmi of December. The naDl remain­ed topped unfit middle of March la-t, when the new capital rsited enabled it to commence work again immediately. After this a further stoppage for a short time Was caused by the break-down Of a driving gliift. Altogether your business|wa' stopped for a period equal to four full months of the year. As it was expected that the [mill might re commence work at any moment, the staff was kept in Cairo daring tho Moi page, and this expense, together with s-tmintotiative expenses going oh as usual, natunillyl ha* causal a big loss to your ochn- pony. Your new directors, therefore, entered office in blaich. last with a loss already made, ami a gtxwl p«t of the new capital raised was ■wallowed uj/at the uut-et in paying off book debts, end in providing a working stock of cotfon and atotca. Owing to the very lad state uf trauc, which has prevailed since, your new directors are sorry to say that this loss h^a been increased, Tho new Board could not have commenced its duties in a worse year, as the cotton trade in that period has been in a very tad ttato all .ovet the world, and few companuM ha>o been able to work without a loss, owing to tho high prices of cottohy brought about by the shortage. At- the outset yonr new; directors were heavily handicapped by finding that most of the cotton of the quality usually employed at the mill had already )«eu shipped to Europe. This neoes- -itoted tiie purchaaeot a slightly bettorquali'y of cotton; at a higher price, but they hoped that an increased, production would make up for this to some extent Owing* to the high prices which your company have had to pay for ite cotton, the working margin has ben bo revised that it has been impossible to wort the mill without a loss. The narrow and in some cases no margin sit all, which manu­facturers in England have had to put up with has affected your concern very'much, inas­much a-, being in competition with English and Indian goods, - prices obtained for onr goods have been affected accordingly. The market in Egypt wax practically without buyers for several months, and prices dropping suddenly in July, we were unluckily caught with large stocks. The yam and cloth mode at the mill are vary well liked, and onr ageqte, Et Oroedi-Back, would have no difficulty whatever in selling the whole of'our pro­duction, in a steady market Salto'doting. August and September were very large indeed and at prices, which go to show that under ordinary conditions of trade your concern would be aooceesfal. A Consider­able sum. of money has bad to be spent on. repairs to plant, this year more than usual, ze repairs, that should have been effected last year, bad to be left over through want,of funds. It will bo Men that this year a profit has been made on our manufacturing account, but heavy payments for excise duty, togeiher with heavy interest charges and other admini­strative expenses, havo not left the rasblt much better than in previous years- A very enoouragfng sign for the future, however, has been ihe 'inoraase in skill in manipulating the machinery at the mill on tho part of the native labour employed. The extent of this increase will be made plain to you, when we say that'the production of tbe mill ! has so increased during the past year that fqlly 30% more weight can now be produoed As com pared with one year ago. This will, fcnsider- ably lessen the fixod charges and ooft of pro­duction in the futore. There is ever*reason, then, to believe that, given ordinary condi­tions of trade in the future, your industry can now be profitably conducted. Since the dose of onr financial year, there has been a great improvement’in the cotton trade, and we are looking forward to better results (luring the present year.

div.head: YOST
div.p:
A new Model of this well-known
TYPEWRITER
is now ready. Many improvements.
Has no Ribbon. Its types strike direct
from an inkpad on to the paper, giving
beautifully clear outlines, and it
has therefore been termed
THE TYPEWRITER FOR BEAUTIFUL WORK.
Made of Best Materials only.
Illustrated Booklet post free.
THE YOST TYPEWRITER Co., Ltd.
H. Holborn, Viaduct, London, E.C,
